body:
Previously, attempting to take the `eigs` of any defective matrix
  was doomed to fail in an attempt to solve a singular linear system.
  This PR detects the situation (as best as it can given the
  inherent numerical instability of the current methods used) and
  handles it. Note that in such cases, it's not possible to return
  a square matrix whose columns are the eigenvectors corresponding to
  the returned eigenvalues. In light of that fact and issue https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/issues/3014, this
  PR also changes the return value of `eigs` so that the eigenvectors
  are passed back in a property `eigenvectors` which is an array of
  plain objects `{value: e, vector: v}`.

  Note that this PR makes the ancillary changes of correcting the
  spelling of the filename which was "realSymetric.js," and replacing
  the now-unnecessary auxiliary function "createArray" therein with
  `Array(size).fill(element)`. The rationale for performing these
  changes not strictly related to the issues at hand is that this
  file is rarely touched and with the level of maintenance hours we have
  at hand, it's more efficient to do these small refactorings in parallel
  with the actual bugfixes, which are orthogonal and so will not be
  obfuscated by this refactor. Note `git diff` does properly track the
  file name change.

  However, it also makes a potentially more pervasive change: in order for
  the numerically-sensitive algorithm to work, it changes the condition
  on when two very close (double) numbers are "nearlyEqual" from differing by
  less than DBL_EPSILON to differing by less than or equal to DBL_EPSILON.
  Although this may change other behaviors than the ones primarily being
  addressed, I believe it is an acceptable change because

  (a) It preserves all tests.
  (b) DBL_EPSILON is well below the standard config.epsilon anyway
  (c) I believe there are extant issues noting the odd/inconsistent
      behavior of nearlyEqual near 0 anyway, so I believe this will
      be overhauled in the future in any case. If so, the eigenvector
      computation will make a good test that a future nearlyEqual
      algorithm is working well.

  To be clear, the direct motivation for the change is that there are
  multiple cases in the eigenvector computation in which a coefficient
  that is "supposed" to be zero comes out to precisely DBL_EPSILON, which
  is fairly unsurprising given that these coefficients are produced by
  subtracting an eigenvalue from a diagonal entry of a matrix, which is
  likely to be essentially equal to that eigenvalue.

  As many tests of defective matrices as I could readily find by web
  searching have been added as unit tests (and one more in the typescript
  type testing). An additional case I found still fails, but in the
  _eigenvalue_ computation rather than the _eigenvector_ search, so that
  was deemed beyond the scope of this PR and has been filed as issue https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/issues/3036.

  Resolves https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/issues/2879.
  Resolves https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/issues/2927.
  Resolves https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/issues/3014.
comments: Looks like I need to add tests in which the precision argument is used to pass the codecov/patch target. I will try that now.

Oh, and I forgot one more excuse/justification for changing nearlyEqual from `< DBL_EPSILON` to `<= DBL_EPSILON`:
(d) this is a breaking change anyway, so being slightly more relaxed in nearlyEqual, which could potentially be a breaking change even though we have no tests that detect that, should be more acceptable than in a regular non-breaking PR.
OK, I think I've covered the review feedback, and I have incorporated an improvement to #2178 that I think is sufficient for the moment.
Thanks for the updates Glen, this looks good to go.
I'll merge the PR into a new `v12` branch instead of `develop`.
This fix has been published in `v12.0.0` now, thanks again Glen!
commit_messages:
fix: Find eigenvectors of defective matrices (#3037)

* fix: Find eigenvectors of defective matrices

  Previously, attempting to take the `eigs` of any defective matrix
  was doomed to fail in an attempt to solve a singular linear system.
  This PR detects the situation (as best as it can given the
  inherent numerical instability of the current methods used) and
  handles it. Note that in such cases, it's not possible to return
  a square matrix whose columns are the eigenvectors corresponding to
  the returned eigenvalues. In light of that fact and issue #3014, this
  PR also changes the return value of `eigs` so that the eigenvectors
  are passed back in a property `eigenvectors` which is an array of
  plain objects `{value: e, vector: v}`.

  Note that this PR makes the ancillary changes of correcting the
  spelling of the filename which was "realSymetric.js," and replacing
  the now-unnecessary auxiliary function "createArray" therein with
  `Array(size).fill(element)`. The rationale for performing these
  changes not strictly related to the issues at hand is that this
  file is rarely touched and with the level of maintenance hours we have
  at hand, it's more efficient to do these small refactorings in parallel
  with the actual bugfixes, which are orthogonal and so will not be
  obfuscated by this refactor. Note `git diff` does properly track the
  file name change.

  However, it also makes a potentially more pervasive change: in order for
  the numerically-sensitive algorithm to work, it changes the condition
  on when two very close (double) numbers are "nearlyEqual" from differing by
  less than DBL_EPSILON to differing by less than or equal to DBL_EPSILON.
  Although this may change other behaviors than the ones primarily being
  addressed, I believe it is an acceptable change because

  (a) It preserves all tests.
  (b) DBL_EPSILON is well below the standard config.epsilon anyway
  (c) I believe there are extant issues noting the odd/inconsistent
      behavior of nearlyEqual near 0 anyway, so I believe this will
      be overhauled in the future in any case. If so, the eigenvector
      computation will make a good test that a future nearlyEqual
      algorithm is working well.

  To be clear, the direct motivation for the change is that there are
  multiple cases in the eigenvector computation in which a coefficient
  that is "supposed" to be zero comes out to precisely DBL_EPSILON, which
  is fairly unsurprising given that these coefficients are produced by
  subtracting an eigenvalue from a diagonal entry of a matrix, which is
  likely to be essentially equal to that eigenvalue.

  As many tests of defective matrices as I could readily find by web
  searching have been added as unit tests (and one more in the typescript
  type testing). An additional case I found still fails, but in the
  _eigenvalue_ computation rather than the _eigenvector_ search, so that
  was deemed beyond the scope of this PR and has been filed as issue #3036.

  Resolves #2879.
  Resolves #2927.
  Resolves #3014.

* refactor: remove comma that lint now doesn't like

* test: add a test for eigs with a precision argument

* feat: Use simple shifts in QR eigenvalue iterations that improve convergence

  Although we might want to use better shifts in the future, we might just
  use a library instead. But for now I think this:
  Resolves #2178.

  Also responds to the review feedback provided in PR #3037.

body:
Hi,

This is an example of a code editor in the browser according to #2719.

I would like to know if the functionality is as expected.

Some features that could be included are:
- save states in local storage
- make more sessions (let's say 10 editors to choose from)
- include comments as markdown in the results
- format the results with latex instead of text
- do the calculations on a web worker

The code could be improved, but first I would like to know if the result is according to your vision and what do you think about the possible features.
comments:
That is a nice editor 😎 ! I like the highlighting of the result when you navigate in the editor. Thanks for sharing. 

The main purpose of the examples is to show how you can use mathjs. In this case: how to couple a code editor with mathjs. If the example turns into a full-fledged application, it will be hard to see the trees from the forest.
 
Would it make sense to make the example that we include in the examples section as bare-bone as possible, and add a reference to a separate git repo with a more extensive editor there? In the separate git repo you can work out the editor in more detail (you list a couple of features that still can be included). If git repo turns out nicely, we can also add a link to in in the Extensions section: https://mathjs.org/download.html#extensions.

Thanks 😄,

It makes sense,

I did include some features that could be removed to simplify a bit:

1. It currently separates the input into paragraphs(blocks), thus creating these chunks of results per paragraph.
2. Has a delay between input and results (so that it doesn't evaluate every keystroke)
3. It splits the input in lines that can be parsed together to match the output. It could be reduced significantly by just evaluating the whole input and show the whole set of results. (Also if a single expressions throws an error, the whole input would throw an error)
4. Has some code that gets the examples from certain functions, it could be reduced by including a text at the beginning

What do you think, shall some of those features be removed to be bare-bone?

I think it would indeed simplify the logic related to separate blocks a bit. It would be nice to keep evaluating lines one by one because else a single line having an error would indeed make the whole output an error.

The delay between input and output makes a lot of sense, I think it is important to show that in the example.

I like the autocompletion, it shows a very useful and tight integration between the code editor and mathjs.

I think it would be easier to grasp what is going on when providing a static string with some initial calculations (maybe take the ones from https://mathjs.org/), instead of smartly loading them via the help examples of a list of functions.

On a side note: what I would love to try out is creating a [CodeMirror decoration](https://codemirror.net/examples/decoration/) that shows the results _inline_, on the next line. I guess that would be a Widget decoration. Is that something you would like to fiddle with too?

Thanks for your inputs!

The use of decoratros is something that I would be interested in implementing to get rid of the right panel.

Sadly I don't have much experience with **bundlers**, thus I was sticking to CodeMirror5 which doesn't have that option.

If you could point me to a way to make a simple CM6 editor the right way within this project I'm interested in migrating the CM5 logic and including the results in decorators which would be really cool.
I'll give it a try and do some fiddling the end of next week, that would be fun. I have some recent experience with CodeMirror6 in a different project, so I'm not a total stranger.
I made a little start, but didn't get very far today: https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs-codemirror
Hi, this is very cool, I was able to work a little on this to include syntax highlighting with a legacy mode. Made a PR

The experiment in https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs-codemirror is quite functional now. Showing results inline adds quite some complexity, so for this example it may be best to take your approach of showing the results in a panel on the right side instead, so we keep the example as simple as possible. So then we just copy the setup of the editor to this example and not the logic for inline results.

Also, the language definition should still be converted to CodeMirror 6 if I'm not mistaken, but I'm not sure what is involved in that and how much work it will be.

Yes, the experiment is fantastic, but maybe not so easy to implement at first.

Regarding the language definition with a non legacy mode I think it's a nice to have, there are many languages that have not made the transition to CodeMirror 6 including Matlab/Octave. A reference for complexity could be Julia that has this [community project](https://github.com/JuliaPluto/lang-julia) but I don't think it should stop this example.

Hi Jos, thanks to https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs-codemirror I think I can translate this simpler example to run with vite now, should that logic be migrated to use webpack to work in this repository?

I think the example should be standalone, and the mathjs bundler should not also bundle examples. So I think you can create a mini project with vite and a package.json in the examples. Does that make sense?

ok, it makes sense, I can include the mini project in examples with vite, but I will definitely need help on how to call the build step outside vite and the folder structure for it to work in the website.

I will work on it and report back.

> I will definitely need help on how to call the build step outside vite and the folder structure for it to work in the website.

Hm, that is a good point. I haven't thought that through. I think we can create a script in `package.json` which goes to the example, runs `npm install` and then `npm run build`. Maybe easiest if I do that myself in the `gh-pages` branch since I can deploy and test that.

Hi, I’ve been working on it and the current state seems approximate to what I would like.

In the following days I will migrate the logic to scroll and highlight the current output and clean up unused files from the CodeMirror5 example.

I think it’s looking good.
O wow that definitely looks good 😎 , the `katex` rendering really makes a difference.

Hi

On the weekend I will remove some unnecessary code and files.
@dvd101x I see you made some more commits. What is the current status of the PR again?

Hi Jos. Thanks for the follow up. It's mostly done.

I would like for you to review how to integrate the build process into the project and webpage. I'm not familiar with how the webpage is built.
👍  I'll have a look, I expect later this week. I see the example already uses `vite`, so maybe all is OK already.

I've had another look at the example. It works like a charm! Qua functionality, I think this is a great example: really rich and fully usable, but still limited enough to see what's going on in the source code.

Some feedbacks:

1. There is an unused file `counter.js` that should be cleaned up I think.
2. I think the example should get a small README.md explaining how to install and run the example.
3. Fix versions in `package.json` to ensure all keeps working in the future. 
4. Set the version number of the example itself to 1.0.0 instead of 0.0.0?
5. Do we really need AlphineJS for this example? Not everyone will be familiar with that. Would the code become more complex when using plain old JS instead? People probably would more easily understand the example and know how to applied the code in their own project.

Hi Jos, thanks for your kind words and thorough review!

I will try to make my code more readable and comment it better.

1. Ok, thanks for catching this!
2. Ok
3. Ok
4. Ok
5. Definitely not mandatory to use Alpine. Somewhere I found the use of lodash and thought Alpine might help reduce the amount of code. I will remove it.
Hi, so far everything is done except removing Alpine, it might be more difficult than anticipated. Might take a while.

🚀  thanks.

Do you want me to give that a try and see if removing Alphine and using plain HTML+JS works out OK?
Yes I would like to try. I'll report back
AlpineJS was removed successfully. I think the behavior is equivalent. Please review and let me know if something is missing.

Thanks for the update David, that looks neat! There is indeed some extra logic now in `updateSelection` but it is easy to understand what is going on there.

When running the example now I get an error, and in the code I see that `processedResults` is undefined in `updateSelection`, and `previousSelectedExpressionIndex` as well. I guess these variables should be defined globally in `main.js`? There is also an unused variable `arrayOfResults`, can you remove that?

Thanks Jos, my bad. At the end I renamed some variables but didn't follow through.

Should be fixed by now.
Thanks! All looks good, merging your PR now.

Hi Jos, thanks for everything!

I was checking today the end result, but didn't find the link in [examples](https://mathjs.org/examples/index.html). Probably because the folders are different. I'm not familiar with the build process for the website, just wanted to let you know.

That is a good point. The script to generate the examples pages on the website should be extended a bit I guess. This script is located in the `gh-pages` branch: https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/blob/gh-pages/gulpfile.js#L166.

body:
This PR modifies the available prefixes for two units of energy in the library:

**erg** had no prefixes available but we find examples of kiloerg, Merg, and others in the wild like [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Convert/list_of_units/energy) and [here](https://lnf-wiki.eecs.umich.edu/wiki/Template:Convert/list_of_units). Adding SHORTLONG prefixes is consistent with the existing unit of bar.

**joule** was set to use SHORTLONG but the short prefixes are not common for this unit. Limiting it to only LONG prefixes is consistent with the existing unit of newton.

Thanks for your consideration!
Carl
comments: Thanks Carl!
Published now in `v11.10.1`, thanks again.

body: partially fixes #3014 #2879
comments: This is not ultimate bug fix nor solution. It still needs much more testing, but this should solve most general case / bug

@been-jamming @nguyenvukhang if you could check if this patch solves your issues / give more examples where it does not work. Thanks

Also if you have explanation/ideas on to how case like `[ [2.0, 1.0], [0.0, 2.0] ]` should be handled - having only one solution (should it be [1, 0] vector or [0, 1] and how to determine it?)

Also if you maybe know the general solution for knowing if it should be transposed (in case of [[1, 2], [4, 3]])

Other than these two cases I don't think I had strange results

@bartekleon From what I can see, it looks like you have added a special case for computing the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of a 2x2 matrix? I ran into the issue when computing eigenvalues of much larger matrices, so I'm not sure if this is a good solution.

> Also if you have explanation/ideas on to how case like [ [2.0, 1.0], [0.0, 2.0] ] should be handled - having only one solution (should it be [1, 0] vector or [0, 1] and how to determine it?)

If there is only one eigenvalue and one eigenvector, then `ans.values` and `ans.vectors` should only contain one entry. But it will probably require work to distinguish between matrices with a single eigenvalue and ones with multiple close eigenvalues. I don't do much numerical linear algebra, so I wouldn't know the best way of going about solving these problems.

> Also if you maybe know the general solution for knowing if it should be transposed (in case of [[1, 2], [4, 3]])

I'm not sure what you mean by this. I mixed up the matrix and its transpose when I created the issue.

> Other than these two cases I don't think I had strange results

I ran into the issue when computing the eigenvectors of a 101x101 matrix, so I think there is something larger wrong with the algorithm used to compute the eigenvectors. In all cases I've tested, the eigenvalues have been correct.
I don't think it's worth adding a special case to the code to fix non-bug #3014. I will take a look at #2879.
#2879 is a problem at all matrix sizes, so again I don't think adding a special case for 2x2 is the answer. Recommend closing this PR.
Moreover, this PR duplicates the identical function eigenvalues2x2 between complexEigs.js and trivialCase.js, which would have to be fixed if it were to move forward.

Agree, I think handling one special case for 2x2 matrices doesn't solve the issue in general. I'll close this PR now. Thanks anyway for working out this PR @bartekleon and thinking along to find a solution!

body:
solution for #3014 

This is a rough version. It might not work for all cases.
comments:
Checklist for implementation (unless decided otherwise):
- [ ] !! Ensure eigenvectors are correct, not only eigenvalues
- [ ] Ensure BigInt working
- [ ] Ensure BigNumber working
- [ ] Ensure Complex working

There are a lot of numerical issues in computing eigenvalues and eigenvectors. The current implementation at least attempts to handle those by "balancing" the matrix, etc. I doubt the solution is to start afresh with a totally new implementation (that will likely have its own collection of shortcomings). But let's keep this concept open until the issue in #2879 is resolved.
Closing as this is 15 months old, and it seems to me that an attack on mathjs eigenvalue computations that would address #3036 would need a fresh start.

body:
> I think we need to think through some steps before we can finish up this PR:
> 
> 1. I think it is essential to have this behavior configured via `epsilon`
> 2. We have to think through how to configure and pass this epsilon, both in the case of the plain number implementation as well as the generic implementation, in such a way that the code base as a whole works consistent.
>    
>    1. I think we should keep all plain number functions as is, without handling round-off errors (and corresponding `epsilon` etc).
>    2. And we should handle round-off errors in all generic implementations (all relational functions, and `mod` and `gcd`). At this level we _do_ have `epsilon` so we can easily use that.
> 3. Concretely: I think the most pragmatic solution is to copy the code of `modNumber` and `gcdNumber` into `mod.js` and `gcd.js`, and then change the implementation to handle round-off errors in a similar way as function `larger` using the util function `nearlyEqual(x, y, epsilon)`.
> 4. We will also need to change the `BigNumber` implementations of `mod.js` and `gcd.js` to handle round-off errors (similar to for example function `larger` and other relational functions.
> 5. We'll need to write unit tests to validate the new behavior.
> 
> What do you think?

To solve issue #2936 raised and based on these requirements written by @josdejong, I've made changes to `mod.js` and `gcd.js` files and `BigNumber` implementation.

I've also added test cases to validate the new behaviour
comments:
Hi @josdejong 
Can you go through my recent commit?
You mentioned something about the `BigNumber` implementation which I didn't quite get but I hope it's the way it should be?

Nice 😎! This is a very elegant solution. 

You've resolved my remark about `BigNumber` by using `floor` there too. (we could go a step further and merge `_gcdNumber` and `_gcdBigNumber` into one but that is out of scope for this PR I think, unless you prefer to do that on the fly).

I have one last remark: you have now extended `src/function/arithmetic/mod.js` to support negative divisors. Can you also change `modNumber` in `src/plain/arithmetic.js` to have the same behavior (except using `Math.floor` there) and add unit tests for it?

Thanks!

I've made changes to the `mod` implementation in `arithmetic.js` but since it's not being imported to be used, there's no way actually to add unit tests to validate it. 

I will look into the `gcd` implementation to see if they can be combined. Because `BigNumber` and `Number` are different, from what I can understand.

> I've made changes to the `mod` implementation in `arithmetic.js` but since it's not being imported to be used, there's no way actually to add unit tests to validate it.

Ah, you're right, the `/src/plain` functions do not have unit tests since they where all covered by the higher level implementations in `src/function`. I think you can create a new test file `/test/node-tests/plain/number/arithmetic.js` and add a test for the function `gcd` from `src/plain/number/arithmetic.js` there.

Please let me know if you need help.

Been a while, but I've added the tests for the function in the new file.

Could you check that out?

Thanks for the updates @praisennamonu1 , this looks good and well tested👌 

I see mentioned putting the new unit tests under `/test/node-tests/plain/number/arithmetic.js`, that should be `/test/unit-tests/plain/number/arithmetic.js`. I'll move the file after merging so we can finish and publish this fix now.
The fix is published now in `v11.11.1`, thanks again Praise!

Hi, this is according to #2989 

There is no rush, please review when possible.

comments:
The shared logic is not much other than the regular expression `/\$[\w.]+/g` (in fact I had a different one, that later on I replaced by the one in `print`)

The logic to split the results by `.` is similar but not the same.

I'm thinking of a few possibilities:
1. From `print` export the regex that `print.transform` can import.
2. Make a separate file that generates the regex and import that from `print` and `print.transform`
3. Use `print` to modify the `print` argument (just an idea that would be difficult to make it work for complex cases) `print("Values: $1, $2, $3", ["", "$0","$1", "$2"])`
4. Maybe leave it as is

You're right, only the regex can be reused. I prefer having the regex defined only once. Can you please implement your option (2), make a file `src/utils/print.js` and add the regex there with a clear name? Thanks!
Hi, thanks. Sounds good I will work on it and report back.
Hi, I included `src/utils/print.js`
Thanks David!
The fix is published now in `v11.11.1`, thanks again!

Unfortunately for the app I work on this was a breaking change and because it was included in a patch release and not a major release it went unreviewed in the package update process. We have to do a bunch of remediations as a result, and will be improving our in-house unit testing of Math.js to try and catch other regressions like this that could affect our app in future, but moving forward is there any policy regarding semantic versioning guarantees in the library?

Semver seems to be the intention, but I couldn't find discussion regarding the breaking nature of this change, is that because it was considered to be a bug? Does Math.js allow bugfixes in patch releases to cause breaking changes to long-standing behaviour, or was it just missed in this instance?

Btw the docs still refer to zero-based indexing here: https://mathjs.org/docs/reference/functions/print.html

Thanks!

I'm sorry to hear that. The library indeed using Semver, and bug fix releases and feature releases should not be breaking. 

Every bug fix changes the behavior of the library (normally for the better), but in this case we should indeed have realized that people may rely on the (non-intended) zero-based behavior and mark it as a breaking change.

> Btw the docs still refer to zero-based indexing here: https://mathjs.org/docs/reference/functions/print.html

The plain functions do use zero-based indexing, and the expression parser uses a one-based version of the function, see docs: https://mathjs.org/docs/expressions/syntax.html#differences-from-javascript

On a side note: in my projects I use exact version numbers so I have full control, and I upgrade them manually once in a while, so I can directly verify that nothing is broken. Even though minor and bug-fix releases should be non breaking, it sometimes happens that there are unforeseen cases.

body:
Hi, while working on #1552 I think this is the minimum changes to make it work, but maybe there are some topics to discuss.

1. By researching `quantileSeq`, I've seen some other references and I think it could be changed to just `quantile`
2. A different method could be implemented for example linear (numpy's default)
3. It could be refactored to use more of `typed` capabilities
4. `utils/lastDimToZeroBased` doesn't apply directly for this function, in my opinion is too specific.
5. Other stat functions are also missing dimensions functionality: `mad`, `median`, `mode` and `prod`
6. It seems like other stat functions could benefit from `apply` to reduce the amount of code

Please let me know if any of these topics could be addresses in this PR.
comments:
The PR looks good and well tested, thanks David. I think we can merge it as-is.

About your discussion points:

1.  Renaming `quantileSeq` to `quantile`: I don't remember why the function was originally named like this. I would prefer not "just" renaming the function, that is a breaking change again. But if there is a good reason for it we can consider it. Is the name `quantile` more common in other applications for example?
2.  I'm not sure what you mean with `A different method could be implemented for example linear (numpy's default)`
3.  Would you like to change `lastDimToZeroBased` to make it more usable in different cases? Do you have a proposal? 
4.  The function `quantileSeq` can indeed use some refactoring if you want to give that a go. A PR would be welcome, but let's please create a separate PR for this.
5.  Yes I would love to add the dimension argument to other functions too. (let's do that in a separate PR :))
6.  Definitely! You're full of ideas to improve the code base :). A separate PR with a refactor would be nice.

Thank you, Jos,

Ok, that sounds good to have those topics on a different PRs. I think I left some unwanted modifications in the docs which I will fix soon.

1. After further review, I noticed `quantileSeq` has a parameter that is not common for other `quantile`, If `probOrN` <= 1 then it is  `prob` as other `quantile` but if `probOrN` is an integer > 1 then it acts differently by splitting the range from 0 to 1 in `N` places and returning an array of `prob` and the rest works like other `quantile`. Here are some references of other `quantile` that are similar between them:
  - https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/stats/versions/3.6.2/topics/quantile
  - https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.quantile.html
  - https://octave.sourceforge.io/octave/function/quantile.html
  - https://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/quantile.html
  - https://reference.wolfram.com/language/ref/Quantile.html
  - https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/stdlib/Statistics/#Statistics.quantile!
2. In numpy there are about 9 different methods to compute `quantile`. The linear method instead of giving the average of two values when it falls in between, does a linear interpolation.
3. Currently `lastDimToZeroBased` is limited to where the number of arguments is exactly two. `quantileSeq` has more than two arguments so it can't use it as such.
4. Ok, I will try
5. Ok, thanks!
6. Ok, thanks! :D
Thanks for the reply and all your inputs of this week and last week on the project David, I'll look into them after the holidays, sorry for the delay.

Hi Jos, thanks for the reply

Please don't worry about it, and have great holidays!
Published now in `v11.10.0`

body:
Hi, regarding #2735 here is a way to do indexing with an array of booleans.

## new capabilities

```
a = [1, 2, 3, 4];
a[[true, false, true, false]]   # yields [1, 3]
a[a > 2]                        # yields [3, 4]

b = [1, 2, 4, 8]; 
a[b < 4]                        # yields [1, 2]

a[a > 2 and a < 4]              # yields 3
a[a > 2 and b < 8]              # yields 3
a[a > 2 and b < 3]              # yields []

A = [1, 2; 3, 4];
A[[false, true], 2]             # yields 4
```

## Main changes:

### `index`

Checks if it's getting an array of only booleans and converts such arguments to a corresponding vector of numeric indices (comparable to octave and numpy)
- currently `index([true, false, true])` is like `index([1, 0, 1])`
- the proposal is that `index([true, false, true])` works like:
  - `index([0, 2])`
  - `index([1, 3])` in the parser

### `subset`
Can use an empty `index` (comparable to octave and numpy)
- `subset(value, index)` returns an empty value of the same type if it has an empty index
- `subset(value, index, replacement)`, returns the value unmodified if it has an empty index

> Note:
> it doesn't check if the size of the array of booleans matches the dimension of the value in `subset` (it's similar to octave, but unlike numpy).
comments:
Thanks so much for the PR submission!

Some comments/questions, not meant to be exhaustive at this point:

(a) I thought we decided in the discussion in #2735 that if A = [1, 2, 3, 4] then A[[true, false, true]] is a dimension error, but the comment above seems to say this PR does not complain and returns [1,3]. Why not adhere to the recommended design?

(b) Reviewing this PR revealed the pre-existing oddity that if B = [1,2;3,4] then (in the parser, easier to test) B[2,2] = 4 and B[2,[2,1]] = [[4,3]] (both pretty much as expected) but B[2,[2]] = 4 . I would expect the latter to produce [[4]]. (Or quite possibly B(2,[2,1]) to produce [4,3] and B(2,[2]) to produce [4], while B([2],[2,1]) produced [[4,3]].)  The current behavior seems to prevent certain dimensionality invariants (based on the dimensions of the matrix being indexed and the shape of the indices) from holding true. I bring these up because they produce the very surprising behavior that B([false, true], [true, true])) is [[3,4]] while B([[false,true]],[[true, false]]) is 3. It seems like a problem to me that the _type_ of the result differs for indices that are identical in type and shape and differ only in the value of a single boolean inside the indices. Hence, should I file the indexing oddity of B[2,[2,1]] vs B[2,[2]] as an issue? And should the boolean indexing wait until that newly surfaced issue is resolved? Or another possibility is to leave B(2,[2]) alone but still have B([false,true],[false,true]) return [[4]]. Thoughts, @josdejong ?

Thanks for the review Glen!

## (a)
I was testing different methods to accomplish this but in the end I couldn't make it work thinking it would introduce breaking changes. The issue I couldn't resolve is.
- `subset` hast the information of the size of the matrix and receives `index` (not the array of booleans). So it doesn't know what was the size of the array of booleans that generated the `index`.
- `index` is the one that receives the array (and checks if it contains only booleans) but it doesn't know what is the size of the matrix it will be used in.

In the end I thought to present this PR that is comparable to what Octave does even though is not as agreed

## (b)

I think this behavior is related to #2344, it might make some cases simpler but in this case it's very odd. I think that behavior is as intended but let's wait for Jos's comments.

In the context of using logic inside of index it's not that odd.

```
A = [10, 20, 30, 40];
A[A > 20] # yields [30, 40]
A[A < 20] # yields 10
```

Maybe a proposal could be that if the index comes from an array, then the result should match the source regardless if it has singleton dimensions.
```
A = [1, 2; 3, 4]
A[1, 2]          # shall return number 2
A[[1], 2]        # shall return [2]
A[1, [2]]        # shall return [2]
A[[1], [2]]      # shall return [2]
```

I think these issues could be addressed independently

Just as an example this is what the parser does with an array of booleans.
```
B = [10, 20, 30];
B[[true]]             # yields 10
B[[true, true]]       # yields [10, 10]
B[[true, true, true]] # yields [10, 10, 10]
B[B > 5]              # yields [10, 10, 10]
```

On (a), I guessed as much, but it seems like it's a case of implementation pushing behavior around. If the behavior desired is the one agreed on in #2735, then it seems like we need to find an implementation that supports that. For example, it could be that index objects are enhanced to allow vectors of booleans within them, and the "index" function just passes such specifiers through, so that subset can have all of the information and deal with it. There may be other possible implementations that would yield the desired behavior, just brainstorming.

On (b),
> In the context of using logic inside of index it's not that odd.
> 
> ```
> A = [10, 20, 30, 40];
> A[A > 20] # yields [30, 40]
> A[A < 20] # yields 10
> ```

On the contrary, I find this extremely odd: depending on what the exact condition is, the result might be a vector or a number? That seems like it will be painful, since I will have to then write the expressions that use the result to handle either. It would seem much preferable that whatever the condition is, it should produce an array/vector as a result, that might have just one (or zero) entries.

> Maybe a proposal could be that if the index comes from an array, then the result should match the source regardless if it has singleton dimensions.
> 
> ```
> A = [1, 2; 3, 4]
> A[1, 2]          # shall return number 2
> A[[1], 2]        # shall return [2]
> A[1, [2]]        # shall return [2]
> A[[1], [2]]      # shall return [2]
> ```
> 
> I think these issues could be addressed independently

I agree that the existing shape-of-indexing-results oddity is the underlying problem, but if it were up to me, I'd first resolve that concern (in a separate issue/PR) before merging this boolean-indexing stuff, because of the very counterintuitive results it produces in the Boolean case. There are various options on how to modify the shapes of indexing results, so I would also suggest first an issue or a discussion to hash out the desired behavior, before a PR addressing the point. But let's see how @josdejong  wants to go -- another position might be to leave the shape of results of numeric indexing alone, and only fix the vector-vs-number inconsistency for Boolean indexing. That's not what I would do, but it's certainly possible to implement.

Fair points

I agree that the flexibility of showing either a number or an array depending on the case is odd for a program.

I was thinking that in a different context wouldn't be that odd. Let's imagine a stack of paper in a box and I try to get them according to an index. If many pages are found they are returned in a manilla envelope, but when only one page is found there is no envelope, I might be glad to see the found page rather than complain about the missing envelope.

both a) and b) are consistent with the way [numpy indexes](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/user/basics.indexing.html), which would be really nice to have in mathjs, but might need more core changes.

In fact the other proposed change that an empty index gets you an empty array makes it even more odd that:
```
A = [10, 20, 30, 40];
A[A > 20] # yields [30, 40]
A[A < 20] # yields 10
A[A > 50] # yields [ ]
```

As if a set of many pages is presented in an envelope, a single page is without the envelope and no pages found gets you only the empty envelope.

So I mostly agree with you, at some point I thought about changing the behavior of index further as you mentioned but thought it might be unwelcome as it wasn't agreed upon. In fact I wasn't sure about returning an empty index (currently it just throws an error)

I see some partial functionality that can be used in the meantime something better comes along, but as you mentioned, let's wait for Jos to weigh in.

As a reference, the current implementation of broadcasting is missing some optimization as making something like [numpy: nditer](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/arrays.nditer.html#arrays-nditer) would require some core changes in the matrix algorithm suite. Currently it is using the mathjs functions to make copies of matrices (requiring more memory) but it's actually working in the meantime an optimized solution can be implemented.

Thanks David!

The logic behind the behavior of the function `subset` is: when the output contains a single, scalar value, unwrap it from the matrix and return the (numeric) value. When the output contains multiple values, return a matrix. I'm just happy with the current behavior, it is very practical when getting/setting individual values in a matrix that you don't have to worry about wrapping/unwrapping the value correctly. Also, I do like this proposal in #2344 to be able to disable this "smart unwrapping" feature if you need predictability. 

I do not really have a strong opinion about how `A[[1], 2]` and `A[1, [2]]` should behave. I think in practice you will not enter a nested array with just one value, so it is a bit of a theoretic case to me. It makes sense to let the output be an array then, instead of the current behavior of returning an unwrapped number.

For the new filtering behavior it makes sense to me to always return a Matrix/Array, and not unwrap the output when it contains only a single value.

Hi Jos, thanks for the review

Only as a reference, It works like this by default:
```
A = [10, 20, 30, 40];
A[A > 20] # yields [30, 40]
A[A < 20] # yields 10
A[A > 50] # yields [ ]
```
And now it includes this behavior with `math.config({ predictable: true})` according to #2344
```
A = [10, 20, 30, 40];
A[A > 20] # yields [30, 40]
A[A < 20] # yields [10]
A[A > 50] # yields [ ]
```

Thanks, that is clear. 

Whilst there is a clear use case to let `A[0]` return a number `10` (and I would like to keep that behavior like it is), I do not see a use case for the filtering functionality returning a number, since a filtering operation in general has an array as input and an array with an arbitrary number of items as output. So I would like `A[A < 20]` to return `[10]` rather than `10` (always predictable). How do you think about that? Does that make sense to you? Or do you see use cases for that?

Here is a possible case for that.
```
A = [1, 2, 3];
B = [4, 5, 6];
A[B == 5] # yields 2 or [2]
```
For me it's the same logic as with regular indexing. If the index is a calculated variable, it's uncertain if the index will contain one or many numbers.

Of course B could have various values equal to 5, so it's not predictable if the indexing with booleans will return one or many numbers.

In the references I know, it usually returns an array (the same as regular indexing in those references). So I don't know if it will also be confusing if the behavior of indexing is different if it comes from an array of booleans.

Hm, yeah that is true, if you have a variable in `A[x]`, the output depends on whether `x` holds a number or a range for example. So, yeah, there is some logic to it.

I just find it odd to have something like `A[A < 20]` or `A[B == 5]` return a number. Would _you_ want that in practice?

Personally I wouldn't. I would prefer a predictable way as it can be used for other steps.

I will look into a way for an array of booleans to always return predictable outcomes regarding of config. If there is some confusion later regarding regular indexing we can take a look into it.

I think this is an in between state at some point it will need to be able to do something like.
```
A = 1:4;
A[A > 2] = 6;
A          # yields [1, 2, 6, 6]
```

Currently this throws a dimensional error but we will need to take a look at some point regarding broadcasting the 6.
```
A[3:4] = 6
```

In this version:
- Index class now
  - Converts an array of booleans to an array of numbers
  - Has a property to indicate the size of the array of booleans
- Return predictable subsets if indexing with an array of booleans
  - for other cases returns predictable subsets if `config.predictable`
- Subsets now validates if the array of booleans had an equal size to the Array|Matrix and throws a dimensional error otherwise.

This behavior of returning a number when indexing with a single number or an array with a single element when indexing with an array of booleans is equivalent to numpy's way of indexing.

One difference is that indexing with booleans returns the same number of dimensions as the source but numpy reduces the other dimensions.

Hi, this version needed the most changes.

To be able to do broadcasting in subsets in the parser it was necessary to move some of the logic from `brodcast.js` to `utils/array.js` so that `DenseMatrix.subset` could benefit from broadcasting the replacement value to match the index size.

Now something like this works both in the parser and outside the parser
```
A = [1, 2, 3, 4]
A[A>2]              # yields [3, 4]
A[A>2 and A<4]      # yields [3]
A[[true, false]]    # yields error due to the not matching origin dimensions
A[A>2] = 1.9;
A                   # yields [1, 2, 1.9, 1.9]
```

I think it's mostly done feature wise from the previous discussion, I expect many changes in the naming conventions or other stuff due to the many changes to make it work. So please let me know.

Umm this latest commit, while looking at it looks like a totally good change, it seems completely orthogonal to the scope of this PR as originally submitted. I don't know how strict Jos likes to be with respect to "well-factored" PRs, so I'll leave it to him to say whether that change should be separated into its own PR.

Hi Glen and Jos,

I'm really glad you are liking the results so far. Thanks for the comments and review!

I agree these are a lot of changes at once, I wasn't planning for this. So thanks for the effort of reviewing this many changes at once and being so understanding of this whole process.
Hi, I think this latest commit covers most of the issues. Please let me know if something is missing.

Thanks David for adding even more tests.

Last question: do we keep the `config.predictable` in this PR or not? See https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/pull/2994#discussion_r1269241026. I see you marked the discussion as resolved, does that mean that you do want to keep it in this PR (so we'll schedule this PR for a new major version)?

Sorry my bad, I was certain I removed that as soon as you asked, either I messed something up with my setup or removed some of that and forgot about other places 

I think it's better now.

OK I took a look through, specific comments above. In general, I think this now leaves prior numeric/numeric array indexing alone, which I think is appropriate, and has the agreed-upon behavior for boolean indexing. So I have no objections to its merge. I will comment a bit on #2344
Good catch on this latest fix to your PR. Should you add a test that would have exercised the problem?

Thanks, Glen

Ok, I will include a test where an array to broadcast to a size that is equal to the array will broadcast correctly (and not skip the broadcast process). I was concerned it might be too specific.

> I was concerned it might be too specific.

Thanks! IMHO no test for something that actually went awry at any point is too specific.
Makes sense, I'll keep that in mind, thanks!

Thanks for reviewing Glen. 

@dvd101x there is still one open comment from Glen about code duplication. Can you reply on that? Besides that I think the PR is ready to be merged :).

Thanks Jos,

I think Glen's comment about code duplication is addressed with the latest commit.

If no other topic is unresolved, I think this is ready to be merged.
Yup, that's the sort of thing I had in mind, thanks. I have no objections to this being merged.
Awesome 🎉. Thanks for your patience David! Going to merge your PR now.
Published now in `v11.10.0`, thanks again!

body:
This PR replaces the default behaviour of AssignmentNode and FunctionAssignmentNode to use `:=` as the Latex output for assignment String. It also forces the ConditionalNode to use `:=` for the condition, trueExpr and falseExpr.

Additionally it uses the `assignString` in `toHTML` and `toString` methods.

In the usual cases for AssignmentNode and FunctionAssignmentNode the user can decide which `assignString` to use. Either by providing the token as "(a := 3)" or by changing the assignString programmatically. Like:

```
n = new AssignmentNode(...)
n.assignString = ':='
```

The default assignString is `=`, as the `:=` is mostly used for definitions, like in the conditional node case. And most visitors are used to the simple `=` syntax.

https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/issues/2979
comments: Found the commit were the assignment was changed to `:=` https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/commit/0868987cdf99d7cf75b95aba639b4369051891ae It was part of more a big refactoring. Unfortunately this part was not discussed at all. And I think the best one can do is to let the user decide, how the representation should look like.

Thanks for working out this PR @webdeb . 

It is an interesting idea to make the assigns string (`=` or `:=`) customizable. I'm in doubt though how big the need for this customization is, and whether it is worth building in a configurable solution for this case. I would like to postpone making this customizable until there is a clear need for it. You're the first that asks to change `:=` to `=`. It can well be that everybody will be just happy when the assignment string is `=` and that's it.

There are workarounds for this BTW: with a simple regex you can replace `:=` with `=` and vice versa. And you can also customize the output by providing a custom handler as described here: https://mathjs.org/docs/expressions/customization.html#custom-html-latex-and-string-output.

Thank you for looking into it!
> It can well be that everybody will be just happy when the assignment string is = and that's it.

I agree, I just thought, that for some cases, you want this to be a real variable definition, like:
```
a := 2
c := 10

f(x) = a^x * b^b 
```
whatever.. also, wasn't sure if this was a **strong** requirement back then. So I thought a flexible solution would fit all needs, if required.

> There are workarounds for this BTW: with a simple regex you can replace `:=` with `=` and vice versa. And you can also customize the output by providing a custom handler as described here: https://mathjs.org/docs/expressions/customization.html#custom-html-latex-and-string-output.

Btw, before opening a new issue, can the handler be globally configured or would you suggest just monkey-patching the `toTex` method?

I've listed the change from `:=` to `=` in the planned breaking changes: #3032

> Btw, before opening a new issue, can the handler be globally configured or would you suggest just monkey-patching the `toTex` method?

You can always write a wrapper function `customToTex(node)` which applies the configuration and changes you want. You can probably also override the method `math.Node.prototype.toTex` though I'm not a big fan of that.
I'll close this PR now since we will go for another solution (simply replacing  `:=` with `=`). Thanks for your inputs!
The assignment operator used in `toTex` is now changed from `:=` to `=`  in mathjs `v12.0.0`
@josdejong I guess, you mean the other way around ;)?
😂  ha, sorry, you're right, I updated my comment.
Thank you!

body:
Based upon #2950 

This PR:

- [x] Refactors the function into a single, generic version that can be used for number, BigNumber, and Complex
- [x] Ensures the results have the desired precision -> for now, we explain the limited precision in the function description
- [x] Extracts the generic implementation so it can be used in the number only version of mathjs -> will not do for now

@Bobingstern I'm working on refactoring your `zeta` implementation. Can you have a look at it to see if this approach makes sense? 

It is working out quite nicely, but I need your help on how to ensure the right precision. For complex numbers, there is a formula:

```js
// The "15" is number of decimal places of accuracy (approx)
const n = Math.round(1.3 * 15 + 0.9 * Math.abs(s.im))
```
Do you know what formula we need to make sure the `number` and `BigNumber` implementation have a precision that corresponds to the configured `config.epsilon`?
comments:
It is tough to say for sure. The formula above is a rough approximation of the number of summands needed to calculate the function. I think simply changing the "15" in that formula to use `config.epsilon` would work just fine. The formula written mathematically is:
To calculate $\zeta(a+ib)$ to $d$ decimals places of accuracy, set $n=1.3d+0.9|b|$. I don't see a major issue with just setting $d$ to the big number precision.
Hmm, I gave it a try but it doesn't magically result in the desired precision (also not with Complex numbers).

You may have better luck using an alternative error bound. I have calculated $$n=\frac{\ln(3\cdot 10^d(2|t|+1)s^{|t|\pi/2})}{\ln(3+\sqrt{2})}$$. If this is still troublesome we may have to resort to the full error bound involving the gamma function which isn't too friendly :(

The error bound for the formulation is 
$$\displaystyle|\gamma_n(s)| \leq \frac{2}{(3+\sqrt{8})^n} \frac{1}{|\Gamma(s)|}\frac{1}{|1-2^{1-s}|} \leq \frac{3}{3+\sqrt{8}} \frac{(1+2|t|)e^{|t|\pi / 2}}{|1-2^{1-s}|}$$ 
and so what I did was use the last expression and take the limit as the real part of $s$ goes to infinity to get the bound needed for large real values. The function is asymptotic anyway so it works fine. I have tested this using both the limit variation and standard one using $s$ and both produce pratically the exact same value for n with Re(s) that are not very close to 1. If they are close to 1 we can just make use of the full formula for calculating n. 
$$\displaystyle n=\frac{\ln\left(3\cdot\frac{10^{d}\left(2\left|t\right|+1\right)e^{\frac{t\pi}{2}}}{|1-2^{1-(\sigma + it)}|}\right)}{\ln\left(3+\sqrt{2}\right)}$$
and for values far larger than 1 just use the limit and say that the term $|1-2^{1-(\sigma + it)}|$ goes to 1
After crunching the numbers, I think you could use
$$0.74+1.55d\ +\ 0.67\ln\left(2|t|+1\right)+1.06|t|$$
The original $1.3d + 0.9|t|$ was actually an underestimate of the actual error. This new one is an overestimate which can be good or bad depending on how you look at it. The full error (if you choose to use it) would be this in expanded form
$$n=\frac{1}{\ln\left(3+\sqrt{2}\right)}\left(\ln\left(3\right)+d\ln\left(10\right)+\ln\left(2\left|t\right|+1\right)+\frac{\left|t\right|\pi}{2}-\ln\left(\left|1-2^{\left(1-\left(a+it\right)\right)}\right|\right)\right)$$
Let me know if this results in the desired precision or not and I can help troubleshoot

Thanks for working out these formulas for the bounds. I did a bit of trial and error but no success yet. I tried the following for the `determineDigits` argument for numbers for example (and the same but with `Math.abs(s.im)` for complex numbers):

```js
value => 0.74 + 1.55 * (12 + 1) + 0.67 * Math.log(2 * Math.abs(value) + 1) + 1.06 * Math.abs(value)
```

Help troubleshooting this would be very welcome.

This is very strange indeed. When I tested it in python it seemed to work fine with all the precision. I suspect an issue with the `d(k,n)` function possibly when n gets large the factorials become too large to store precisely causing loss in decimal digits. Maybe replacing it with a big number variant may work...?

> Maybe replacing it with a big number variant may work...?

I don't think that will make a difference since the number of digits is not a huge number nor does it need a lot of precision.
Any other ideas to get the precision of the function under control?

@gwhitney do you maybe have an idea on how to ensure the accuracy of this new `zeta` function? 

If not, I propose we leave it as it is and add a comment in the docs that the function has a limited precision of about 6 digits.
Sorry for the long delay, I was on vacation. I'm not sure why the precision is not working but I'll continue searching. For now we can just leave it at 6 digits of accuracy I think

I've tried to extract the internal `zetaNumeric` function so we can use it for the number only mathjs, but it is not turning out how I want. I'll leave it as it is for now. We can always have a look again in the future.
Published now in `v11.10.0`

body:
The unit conversions with offset, like temperature, accumulate an unsightly roundoff error near zero:

```javascript
math.unit('32 degF').to('degC').toString()
"5.684341886080802e-14 degC"
```

This pull request sets the conversion result to exactly 0 if it is within `config.epsilon` of 0.
comments:
I agree that the string rendering of the value that should be exactly zero is unsightly. However, I would argue the issue should be handled in the string rendering of the value rather than at the conversion calculation level. The proposed implementation uses `config.epsilon` in a way that doesn't match the [documented purpose of `epsilon`](https://mathjs.org/docs/core/configuration.html), which may be surprising to users (especially if they ~reduce~ increase the value of `epsilon` not expecting it to impact actual calculations). Second, it appears as though the proposed implementation would apply to both bignumber conversions and regular number conversions, thus significantly reducing the precision of bignumber calculations for values near zero.

One solution that can be used by the user of the library would be to use `format` rather than `toString` and to use the option to pass a callback function to `format` to round the number to the desired precision before the string rendering:

```javascript
> math.unit('32 degF').to('degC').format((value) => math.round(value,2).toString())
'0 degC'
``` 
The benefit of this approach is that it works with other conversions that should be exact as well such as the conversion of -40 degrees:
```javascript
> math.unit('-40 degF').to('degC').toString()
'-39.99999999999997 degC'
> math.unit('-40 degF').to('degC').format((value) => math.round(value,2).toString())
'-40 degC'
```

I agree, this is not ideal and it is a misuse of `config.epsilon`.
I thought we could handle this special case of round-off at its source but I'll have to think about it more. Rounding everything to 2 decimal places is not a good solution for me either.

Rounding to 12 digits works as well and will give approximately the same precision as using epsilon since epsilon is 1e-12 by default:

```javascript
> math.unit('32 degF').to('degC').format((value) => math.round(value,12).toString())
'0 degC'
> math.unit('-40 degF').to('degC').format((value) => math.round(value,12).toString())
'-40 degC'
> math.unit('1 degF').to('degC').format((value) => math.round(value,12).toString())
'-17.222222222222 degC'
````

There's not a great way to get around the rounding issue at the unit conversion level when using the javascript number type since it's running into the [limitations of floating point math using the IEEE 754 standard](https://javascript.plainenglish.io/why-0-1-0-2-0-3-in-javascript-d7e218224a72). Here's the raw calculation using the javascript number type:

```javascript
> (32+459.67)*(1/1.8)-273.15
5.684341886080802e-14
```

Ideally, using the mathjs bignumber type would solve this issue since it doesn't face the same limitations as IEEE 754 floating point math. However, due to the way some of the conversion scaling factors are defined, using bignumber does not solve this particular issue:

```javascript
> math.unit(math.bignumber(32), 'degF').to('degC').toString()
'2.1852e-14 degC'
```
The bignumber issue arises from the definition of the of the temperature [scaling factor](https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/blob/23cf6e8035237747f5d197e659eeeaab3996bd89/src/type/unit/Unit.js#LL2312C1-L2312C22). Since `1/1.8` cannot be represented exactly as a javascript number type,  the precision is lost at the time of definition. Because of this, the later [conversion to bignumber](https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/blob/23cf6e8035237747f5d197e659eeeaab3996bd89/src/type/unit/Unit.js#LL837C13-L837C26) does not restore the precision.

Thanks for your PR Carl! 

A value like `"5.684341886080802e-14 degC"` does indeed look ugly. Whether or not this value is "about zero" depends on your context though. For example 1 electron volt is `1.602176565e-19 joule` and we should not round that to zero. We could make this behavior dependent on the type of unit, but I think that will become complex and unpredictable from an end user point of view.

Now, the `.toString()` methods are simple and do not apply rounding. I think that is a good default behavior. You can use `.format({ precision: 12 })` for example if you do want to round the output to make it better readable. It will not round values close to zero though.

In general, mathjs recons with an epsilon in functions like `equal` and when formatting numbers using `format`. It uses a relative difference which works very well, except that it can't know when a value is close to zero. I think we should keep the behavior of `Unit.toString()` in line with the library as whole though, and keep it as is. What do you think?

Docs: https://mathjs.org/docs/datatypes/numbers.html#equality
Related discussions: #1614, #2752, #2518

This PR is only applicable to the very limited situation of unit conversions involving different offsets. This unique situation accumulates round-off errors which are beyond the precision of the offsets themselves. It seems like the appropriate place for improvement is within the `.to` method where the round-off happens, not necessarily in the `.toString` which affects everything.

Anyway, this latest commit adds a few more unit tests and it uses the `Fraction(5, 9)` to more accurately represent 1/1.8. This is not perfect but it is able to pass the major tests which the current develop branch will fail.

I greatly appreciate the discussion. It has already allowed me to make a reasonably robust solution in my own project. I certainly understand that using a Fraction in the unit value is a big change and perhaps not the direction we want to go but I was pleasantly surprised at how easy it was to implement.

Thanks Carl, I really like the idea of defining units as an exact fraction whenever possible! This would indeed be a breaking change though. Some thoughts:

1. Right now, mathjs does not allow implicit conversion from Fraction to BigNumber, so you can't combine those in a single expression. The following gives an error right now:
    ```js
    math.evaluate('unit(fraction(2,5), "degF") + unit(bignumber(10), "degF")')
    // TypeError: Cannot implicitly convert a Fraction to BigNumber or vice versa. Use function bignumber(x) to convert to BigNumber or fraction(x) to convert to Fraction.
    ```

    I think the reason for that was that you can lose precision when moving away from a Fraction. But that may be OK.
2. Right now many constants have two implementations: if you ask `math.pi` you get a `number`, and if you configure `math.config({number: 'BigNumber'})` you will get a `BigNumber` implementation. We could do the same for the relevant units, and extend this mechanism to also create units as Fraction when you have configured `math.config({number: 'Fraction'})`. This last configuration option is a bit tricky though in general, and I'm not sure if that gives a usable solution.

Hi Jos,

I'm not sure I understand your thought 1; there is no implicit conversion needed. The `Unit.typeConverters` are called so the returned value type is matching the original value type. This is the same behavior as the current method. The incompatibility is with the type of `math.Unit.UNITS.degF.value` which is probably not accessed by most users.

## Current
```javascript
math.Unit.UNITS.degF.value                    // 0.5555555555555556
math.unit(98.6, 'degF').toNumeric('degC')     // 37.00000000000006
math.unit(10.5, 'degC',).toNumeric('degF')    // 50.899999999999935
```
## Proposed PR
```javascript
math.Unit.UNITS.degF.value                    // Fraction(5, 9)
math.unit(98.6, 'degF').toNumeric('degC')     // 37
math.unit(10.5, 'degC',).toNumeric('degF')    // 50.9
```

This is the internal calculation:
```javascript
f = math.fraction(5, 9)
f*98.6 + Number(math.subtract(math.multiplyScalar(f, 459.67), 273.15))  // 37
```

Ah, I see what you mean. You want the `toNumeric()` to replace any internal Fraction with a number. I think that is best not to do, because when I explicitly create an unit holding a fraction, like `math.unit(math.fraction(1/3), 'cm')`, I would like to let `toNumeric()` return this fraction, and not convert it to a different numeric type. I think `Unit` itself should be agnostic to what numeric type it is dealing with exactly. Does that make sense?

Hi Jos, sorry but I think you misunderstood. The returned value type is matching the original value type. This is the same behavior as the current method. The use of the Fraction(5,9) internally provides additional accuracy but does not affect the returned type. For example:
```javascript
math.unit(math.fraction(32,1), 'degF').toNumeric('degC')    // Fraction(0,1)
```

To make sure we're on the same page: what would the type of the internal `math.unit(98.6, 'degF').value`? A number or a Fraction? At what moment do we switch from number to Fraction and back to number in the expression 
`math.unit(98.6, 'degF').toNumeric('degC')`? 

> This is the internal calculation:
> 
> ```js
> f = math.fraction(5, 9)
> f*98.6 + Number(math.subtract(math.multiplyScalar(f, 459.67), 273.15))  // 37
> ```

To really utilize Fractions, all operations should be done with Fractions and only at the end we should convert the result to a number. Else you'll introduce rounding errors halfway the operation. So I think the proposed internal calculation should be something like the following, which results in a Fraction right now:

```js
f = math.fraction(5, 9)
math.add(math.multiply(f,98.6), math.subtract(math.multiply(f, 459.67), 273.15)) // Fraction 37
```


Right now, when you do a mixed operation like `math.multiply(f,98.6)`, the number `98.6` will be turned into a Fraction (implicit type conversion), then two fractions are multiplied, and the result is a Fraction. So, naturally, `math.unit(98.6, 'degF').value` would be a Fraction when we change `math.Unit.UNITS.degF.value` into a Fraction and operate on that. 

I think that if we go this route, `math.unit(98.6, 'degF').value` should be a Fraction, and the conversion to a number should only be done at the last step. What are your thoughts?

> what would the type of the internal math.unit(98.6, 'degF').value? A number or a Fraction?

This value is a number type, exactly like it has always been. This is due to the [liberal use of `_getNumberConverter` within the `_normalize` method](https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/blob/bf911816d3644e2780506930a0868484cd437630/src/type/unit/Unit.js#L499C1-L504) which was not altered by this PR.

> At what moment do we switch from number to Fraction and back to number in the expression
math.unit(98.6, 'degF').toNumeric('degC')?

The use of fractions happens inside the `to` method which is called by `toNumeric`. The `to` method [uses `_getNumberConverter` at the end](_getNumberConverter) so that the numeric type of the unit's value remains consistent. This is enough to provide a big improvement in accuracy without unexpectedly changing the value to a fraction. It also avoids the possible loss of accuracy converting a BigNumber value into a fraction. The user still has the option to store value as a fraction if they define the unit with that type like this: `math.unit(math.fraction(98.6), 'degF')`

The PR includes a [handful of new tests, including tests with BigNumbers](https://github.com/costerwi/mathjs/blob/b0f1353f2bfce8cd937419e2b798285210405f04/test/unit-tests/type/unit/Unit.test.js#L300C1-L313), which might help to demonstrate its advantage. All of these new tests are passing in the PR but failing in the develop branch.

Ahh, I finally get it 😅, thanks for your patience. 

I was assuming that `.value` would have to be a `Fraction` in order not to lose precision when converting °C to °F for example, but now I see that (a) in the method `.to()` you defer converting this Fraction to number until after the operations (so the operations are done as Fraction), and (b) when constructing a Fraction, the value is already normalized into the number type of the input number (in method `_normalize`). This is indeed a perfect solution, and I don't think it has side effects 😎 .

Two remarks:

1. Is there a special reason you do the last `addScalar` after `convert`? I guess we can do `convert` last and wrap it around `addScalar`? 
2. In `._normalize()` and `._denormalize()` we too have a couple of conversions first and an operations next. Should we change that too to first do the operations and last the conversion? I can't come up with a case (it's like finding an `0.1+0.2` example that accidentally has a round-off error), but I guess it can happen with specific combinations of an input value and 1/1.8.

If we simply `addScalar` _before_ `convert` then, when the value is a BigNumber, we get this TypeError in `addScalar` so we must chose a type:

> Cannot implicitly convert a Fraction to BigNumber or vice versa. Use function bignumber(x) to convert to BigNumber or fraction(x) to convert to Fraction.

There is a potential loss of accuracy converting number or BigNumber into Fraction so the PR is a safe compromise to perform the `convert` just before the `addScalar`.

Similarly for `.normalize()` and `._denormalize()` I think we could lose accuracy if we try to perform all calculations as Fraction and then convert at the end.

I understand it, that makes sense.

Ok let's leave the PR as it is right now, it looks solid. Thanks again, I'll merge it now!
The fix has been published now in `v11.9.0`

body:
The expression parser `math.evaluate` currently has some confusion between the unit `min` (minutes) and the function `min` (minimum). Similarly for `sec` (seconds) and the function `sec` (secant). Presently, the units are mistakenly recognized as functions in the parser and results in errors. This issue was raised in #2095 and in later discussion within #2771 

It seems to me that function names should always be followed by left parenthesis "(" and the proper fix would be to have the parser look for that character to recognize any function. A fix like that should allow functions and units to coexist so that the user could even define _new_ functions with names that match unit names without trouble. Currently, new functions like this will fail just like the built-in `sec` and `min`.

I'm not familiar enough with the code to implement a change like describe above so, for a temporary workaround, I've added a regular expression to immediately rename any `min` and `sec` units found in the parse expression.
comments:
The naming conflicts between functions and units `sec` and `min` are indeed unfortunate. We've been thinking about these naming conflicts before. 

The way that symbols are resolved is: look it up in the provided scope, then look it up in the `math` namespace, and lastly, try to look it up as a unit. To resolve the naming conflict like you propose, we need to know whether the symbol will be invoked as a function or not. In a case like `min(...)` this is possible. But since mathjs supports lambdas, you do not always know upfront how a symbol will be used. In the following example we cannot know whether we must resolve `min` as function or as unit:

```
up = true
f = up ? max : min
f(values)
```
Because of this ambiguity, we decided to not resolve symbols based on usage the context. As a user of the library you can alter the behavior though if you want: you simply chose one of the two by defining a variable, or you can write a preprocessor like you did if you want to utilize context information. But there is not a one-size-fits-all solution I think.

And another workaround: wrap the unit in the function, like `unit('2 minute') - unit('2 min')`

body:
Hi, this includes a function to do numeric integration of ordinary differential equations in a similar fashion to [scipy.integrate.solve_ivp](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.integrate.solve_ivp.html).

It includes Runge-Kutta methods with variable step size 'RK45' and 'RK23'.

Some ideas for the future are:

- Include an array like for tolerance for each element in the state (currently it calculates only with the maximum value of the error)
- Include tEval option so that it guaranties that every one of the times in that array are returned and no other one (internal steps might vary).
- args: include extra arguments to the function so if a function already exists of the form `myF(t, y, a, b, c)` we could  include in options `{args: [a, b, c]}` instead of making a new function of the form `f(t, y)`
- Once there is a root finding algorithm in numeric, implement other methods like:
  - BDF
  - LSODA

body:
For some engineering notation cases, `math.format` outputs full precision for `bignumber` input when the input has 3 or more significant figures, the desired output has a precision of 1 or 2, and the coefficient of the engineering notation result has 2 or 3 digits. See the previous output below:

```
> format(bignumber(777777.77), { notation: 'engineering', precision: 1 })
'777.77777e+3'
> format(bignumber(777777.77), { notation: 'engineering', precision: 2 })
'777.77777e+3'
> format(bignumber(-.000000000777777), { notation: 'engineering', precision: 2 })
'-777.777e-12'
```

After this fix, the output becomes:

```
> format(bignumber(777777.77), { notation: 'engineering', precision: 1 })
'800e+3'
> format(bignumber(777777.77), { notation: 'engineering', precision: 2 })
'780e+3'
> format(bignumber(-.000000000777777), { notation: 'engineering', precision: 2 })
'-780e-12'
```
Tests have been added for the -12, -3, 0, and 3 power cases for both positive and negative input and all of the existing tests pass.
comments:
Thanks for the feedback. In the branch of code for where I was using `Number` and `toString`, the max number size is 999 (max size of a coefficient in engineering notation) and the max precision is 1 or 2 (the case of 1 or 2 precision is the only time `valueStr` results in a number in scientific notation from the `toPrecision` method since insignificant zeros are not output, 1e2, for example, instead of 100). However, your suggestion of sticking with BigNumber and using `toFixed` is more consistent with the surrounding code and a better solution since it doesn't rely on the particularities of `toString`.

I've incorporated your proposed changes and it does indeed work with all of the tests and solves the original issue.

After adding the constructor trick you suggested, I did notice that the original JSDoc for the `value` input parameter specified a type union of `BigNumber | string`, however `string` would generate an error in the new code (and also for the previous code since it already accesses the `.e` property and the `.mul` member function). I removed the string type since it would have generated an error in the old code and the new code. It looks like there is already a [type gaurd](https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/blob/23cf6e8035237747f5d197e659eeeaab3996bd89/src/utils/string.js#L68) to prevent this function from being called with a string input and it looks like the same function [handles strings separately](https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/blob/23cf6e8035237747f5d197e659eeeaab3996bd89/src/utils/string.js#L88).

I found an additional issue with format and bignumber. Setting precision to zero for 'fixed' notation results in full precision. The issue was related to treating a precision of 0 as undefined since 0 is falsy. I have added the fix to this pull request since it's related to formatting big numbers and the fix is pretty simple. If you would prefer me to split it out, let me know and I can revert the commit and create a separate pull request. 

#### Details of issue and results of applying the fix:

Old behavior:
```
> format(bignumber(1.333), {notation: 'fixed', precision: 0})
'1.333'
> format(bignumber(1.666), {notation: 'fixed', precision: 0})
'1.666'
```

New behavior:
```
> format(bignumber(1.333), {notation: 'fixed', precision: 0})
'1'
> format(bignumber(1.666), {notation: 'fixed', precision: 0})
'2'
```
With the proposed fix, the behavior of format with bignumber matches the behavior with number.

Sorry for the late reply, and thanks for the updates, and for the additional fixes, nice👌 

This looks like a solid and well tested fix, merging it now.
Published in `v11.8.1` now, thanks again!

Sounds great, thanks for rolling out a new version, will be incorporating into my project the next time I push out an update (I'm currently running this fix as  a patched version of mathjs). Thanks for this excellent project, much appreciated!
